text: thanks for coming out today so our biomechatronics lab is dedicated to improving Quality of Life by enhancing
the functionality of artificial hands in human machine systems and we really think a lot about touch so you'll see
that throughout this talk we study human grasp and manipulation as inspiration we design tactile sensors and tactile
perception algorithms and then we leverage sensorized systems to advance robotic grasp and manipulation
um but I'm going to put in a Shameless plug right now because tis the season for faculty hiring so if you're on the

now watch what happens when the sensory perception is turned on
it's like night and day but then when I grab it

oh don't feel pain them to me when I grab a block to me it doesn't it feels like my hand

four years ago something powered by a battery and made of plastic metal and
silicon can become his hand all right so I'm gonna have little
Snippets of things throughout this talk that'll kind of be formatted like this where it just gives you some insights
into how our lab thinks about touch and the first one is that touch is useful and I saw on your robotic seminar series
um itinerary from this past quarter that you've had previous speakers on touch so hopefully I'm preaching to the choir
here but a touch is useful whether it's for machines that are working within the human body are intimately attached to
the human body are working close to the human body whether at home or on the manufacturing line or in places where
you do not want to put humans in order to keep them safe so search and rescue handling of dangerous materials whether
that's decommissioning nuclear sites or looking for explosive ordinance or in very extreme environments like
underwater or in space and for all of these applications you
know of course we're going to use all of the sensory data that we have available to us especially Vision which can be
used for planning and also reactive control however there are many
times when you may not have a direct line of sight or the hand itself is including the object that you're trying
to manipulate you're in the dark you're behind obstacles or inside containers or you may have Vision but it's it's
limited so maybe you're in a wildfire so there's smoke or you're in turbid water
and of course if you're going to work with more complicated materials or objects that are not strictly rigid and
for which you may not have a model there are times when you can use Vision to look at the pose or configuration of
the item but from just a straight rope you cannot tell what is the tension in
that rope and that's something where complementary senses like tactile sensing and proprioception become
especially useful so also manipulating deformable thin sheets or even deformable bulk materials
and maybe someday even bulk but animate objects that have their own their own
agency as well and then of course I had to throw an in-hand manipulation one of the grand challenges for a robot grasp
and manipulation so touch is multifaceted and I'm going
to show you a variety of different tactile sensors that we work with we're agnostic when it comes to tactile
sensing I don't think there's any one piece of technology that that rules them all it really is very application
dependent and I don't think that any of our artificial tactical centers come
close to the beauty of human biological mechanoreceptors which have very specialized mechanoreceptors spread out
in clever ways so for example you might have super a superficial layer of
Miser corpuscles or Merkel discs or you have other petini and petini-like and
raffini mechanoreceptors in the Deep part of the skin and within each of
these layers you also have mechanoreceptors that respond to transients so things like vibrations and
fast changes but also to slow static sustained strain
and so this is you know what what I think a lot of people designing tactile
sensors aspire to um I don't think we're there yet but we're we're working on pieces of it so
I'm going to begin with some of the the low-cost DIY types of sensors Piezo
resistive fabric sensors are one type where you have layers and of course the material itself is responsive to a
strain we also have a barometer based sensors so taking barometers that you
can get for your cell phones but embedding them in elastomer that you cure within a vacuum and now when you
press on the vacuum you can measure some change it's a little bit crude but you can measure some forces being applied to
that bulk material within which the barometers are embedded uh if you have a little bit more access
to specialized equipment you can do microfluidic tactile sensor skins this is a collaboration with Jonathan Posner
we were next to our office Neighbors at Arizona State and now he's up at University of Washington and his team
will make sensors and we characterize them and adapt them to robots in our lab but about a decade ago we started at
Arizona State just taking liquid metal and using them as both wire paths and
sensing tackles so where you see these paths crossing over crossing over one
another they're not intersecting they're actually crossing over and where they pass over one another you get a little
capacitive taxal or a tactile analog to the pixel but when we uh and this
actually only senses normal force because we're just squeezing it along this direction but if you want to design
something for a Shear Force we we switched from the capacitive approach to a resistive approach so just think of
these as liquid metal strain gauges that you can put in the serpentine Direction which now has a direction of greatest
sensitivity or the circular patterns that allow you to measure force in
normal force in equally in all directions and so if you use both of
these patterns you can use pairs of these Serpentine um strain gauges to measure Shear
strength so if you put your finger down on a the armrest near you and you shift your finger left to right and think
about where you're feeling the strain in the skin you probably feel something near your nail bed and that's exactly what we did
here is we put pairs of these along where a nail bed would be so that you
can measure Shear in that direction and then you can imagine if you put another pair here you'll get sheer in that
orthogonal direction but the nice thing is if you can sense from way back here
where there's not even contact with an object it leaves all of this real estate open for the normal taxes that where you
expect direct contact so that was the idea behind that design and more recently we've taken that
design made it a little bit bigger and have been working on making it useful underwater under pressure so we had to
build a lab bench set up to pressurize the system apply stimuli and and calibrate
we also like many groups have been working with camera based elastomeric tactile sensors these are all the rage
because all the computer vision algorithms can be directly applied to the tactile data and you can look at the
tactile flow this is a collaboration with Ted Adelson at MIT who created the gel site
but the idea is that you have a camera embedded within the finger that looks
out at the world through this um elastomeric finger pad and if you put an
array of dots on the inside you can track the optical flow and then for local geometry forces and torques and
some more recent papers coming out of different groups have now started playing with the transparency of the
Skin So if you make the skin more transparent or even have a way to go from transparent to
opaque you can use this same setup for proximity sensing so that's a really exciting development
and of course if you want to go the open source route Facebook or meta now has a
recipe for the digit which we have recently been customizing by putting markers on the inside and adapting them
to different sensors in our robots in our lab but the sensor you're going to see
throughout most of the rest of the talk is the biotech and that's because I worked on it when I was a postdoc with Jerry Loeb at USC it was funded by the
DARPA revolutionizing Prosthetics program at the time so it was bio inspired and intended to go on prosthetic hands and so it has a rigid
core like the bone in your finger an elastomeric skin that's inflated away from the core by a conductive fluid on
the surface of the coral have an image later in the talk but there is an array of electrodes and if you track how the
skin moves toward and bulges away from that that array of impedance electrodes you can infer what's happening to the
overall shape of the finger pad and basically for free if you tap into this fluid volume with an off-the-shelf
pressure sensor that's housed safely in the core you can now have a hydrophone that you can sample slowly to measure a
crude measurement of overall fingertip force or a sample up to 2200 Hertz and pick up vibrations and vibrations
associated with different textures for example there's also a thermistor in the front
of the fingertip and you can use the rate of heat conduction away from the finger to infer material properties
so it can be overkill for many of the applications that you might be interested in but because we already had
a bunch of them we we use them on all of our systems and then we did ablation studies after the fact to test what
would happen if you didn't have different types of modalities how would the performance of your algorithm go
down okay so I showed you hardware for
transducing mechanical stimuli or in some cases thermal stimuli but those are
still just an array of numbers that are flowing in real time so how do we make sense as humans or even robots
make sense of the data to make decisions well I would say that touch is
abstraction because you need to take those numbers and somehow abstract them to Concepts that we can make sense of or
maybe in the case of you know reinforcement learning maybe they're things that we don't fully understand but that an algorithm can use to improve
its performance so by abstracted features I'm talking about things like texture hardness Global shape local
shape and this classic paper from Lederman and klasky in the 80s
basically defined what's called an exploratory procedure these are movements that are specifically taken to
extract certain types of information so if I ask you what is the roughness of
the seat that you're sitting in now you should be imagining what you do to to answer that question and you're
likely to rub your finger against the seat because that is a very typical exploratory procedure when you are
seeking information about texture just as squeezing gives you information about hardness or hefting something against
gravity gives you information about weight so what we did a little close to
a decade ago was We performed exploratory procedures with a sensorized
robot and we looked at edges Edge orientation with respect to the body local features
like bumps pits of different sizes and shapes and what we were after was a way
for the robot to classify or infer the features that it was sensing so it
could decide what it wanted to do next so just as you reach into your pocket and you're able to find the power button
on your cell phone that's something that we wanted to give you know a robot the ability to do without Vision to just
feel and know okay I'm feeling an edge and I can follow that edge so that was
our first foray into machine learning we were using things like support Vector machines back in the day now we use
things like convolutional neural networks this is more recent work on the tactile perception of directionality and
by directionality I mean you're holding an object and either someone is taking it from you or you're interacting with
the environment and you can feel through the object some forces on your fingertip what is the direction of that for us
that's that's what this algorithm will tell you and so instead of moving an
object with respect to the fingertips we just reversed it for all of our data collection to move the fingertips
relative to the objects and you'll see as we do this that you can actually see the the finger pad changing shape
and so we do this thousands of times collect a bunch of training data and
this is the finger core the biotech core without the skin so you can see this array of electrodes we roughly know the
location of these and we only have 19 of them and so in order to apply computer
vision type approaches we use interpolation to create a manifold and
what's on the z-axis here is the change in electrode impedance so when that
change increases and goes positive we know that the skin is getting compressed toward the core of the finger if it goes
negative we know the Skin's bulging away and then we can turn that into a grayscale image where the intensity
refers to the change in impedance over that particular region of the finger pad
and then of course if you do that for a bunch of the different directions you can see that there are patterns here and
so our convolutional neural networks are able to figure that out so this is an example of the real time
playing of the policy or the the model that's learned
so purposely we had the robot grasp the object but only release when it was the
appropriate context which is when someone's pulling the object away from the robot when the line points away from
the Palm is when the robot will release and the sensitivity of this is something that that you could adjust for your
application this is showing interactions with the environment so as the upward
relative upward movement of the glass is sensed when the object's being placed again without Vision the robot can
respond appropriately to release the glass but one of the things that we've been
working on most recently that's I think kind of fun and has been surprising in terms of the things that we've been
discovering is putting tactile sensors in granular media because you've seen robots that are digging through walking
across running across granular media but they don't typically have tactile sensors and we were funded by the Office
of Naval Research to look for buried objects that might be fragile or you may
not want to interact with them directly or do it very carefully and so one of the things that that we thought was
going to be a liability and really annoying is the fact that media granular media the particles can act like fluids
or solids depending on how they're packed and how you're intruding upon them so if you're intruding and dragging
your finger through there will be some particles ahead of you that that freely move kind of like a liquid but at some
point if that wedge of particles that's moving ahead we call it the the soil
failure wedge in the literature if that wedge tip hits something that's buried
what is created is this chain of particles a force chain that will now
push back on your finger even even though you're not directly touching the object and what we thought was that well
this kind of gives our tactile sensor in granular media proximity sensor-like capabilities so
there's a kind of nice parallel between using tactile sensors in granular media with jamming to traditional slam
approaches we're using a proximity sensor to map something out and that was our approach here so what
you're going to see is in this video the little white dots are the you know the
pixels that are changing and there's going to be a little um soil failure region here that moves
ahead of the finger and up in the upper right hand corner just know that those are two measurements of you know roughly
the force or the torque on the fingertip and you'll see that there will be an
increase in the force on the fingertip when that soil failure wedge hits this
buried object but the fingertip has not yet reached it
so this is the soil moving ahead of the finger
foreign there we start to see an increase because of that granular media jamming
so if you know or can characterize the properties of the granular media you can
use that to reduce uncertainty in the map that you're building of the buried object so that's what we did we're
leveraging this transition from free movement to some some jamming statement
we have a different paper in the works that gets more into greatly media jamming with different types of
materials but for this project we used a heterogeneous sand mixture with pebbles
and things and this shows how we can turn this data along with exploratory
movements into Bayesian Hilbert map that tells us about occupancy so you'll see one exploratory movement
from that hand and that's what we infer from that one movement then we have a
second one and with each increase or update in this map you can think about how to plan the
next exploratory movement to reduce the uncertainty in your current map and after about I think seven movements here
we're able to have a decent occupancy map of the object that we then
uncovered to show where it was but of course touch is very expensive so
if if you anyone here collects tactile sensor data you'll know it takes a lot of effort to get the robot Hardware up
and running to program it to collect thousands of Trials of data sometimes the sensors can break or wear out the
bio attack that I showed has fingerprints on the skin to amplify vibration and you will wear out the
fingerprints that's a consumable that you have to replace so touch is very expensive I can't go cannot go online
and download millions of images to perform data mining with I actually have
to collect the data so I have a couple examples here of projects where we wanted to
demonstrate the ability for the robot to learn a hard to code skill and in this case we're closing a Ziploc bag but you
can think of it as a functional Contour following task where both the tactile sensor and the object being manipulated
is deformable and we don't have good models for them I think now there's a
better model of the biotech out there but it's still not an analytical model it's um so yes with the biotech model we
can model the deformation of the finger Pad but we don't really have a good model for the electrical
phenomenon happening within the pad with respect to the impedance electrodes so for that you can bridge that Gap with
actual tactile sensor data and neural networks and that's what the literature has done so here we have set up a camera
to track the motion of the the fingers relative to this zipper we do that to
automate the learning process but once the policy is learned we can turn that off and it'll work so this is just
demonstrating what would happen if you tried naive linear trajectories relative
to a linear zipper that you may be able to view with computer vision but at some
point the finger will probably fall off of the zipper unless you make corrective movements because of the way that the
the bag will deform so what we did this was our first foray
into reinforcement learning so we took a very simple primitive approach and we said okay what are the different states
and Rewards well we'll have three states low Center and High and ideally you keep
that sweet spot of the finger pad aligned with the zipper because otherwise you're going to fall off the
zipper right either too low or too high and let's reward for being in the center and then this asymmetric set of actions
came about after some pilot studies but these are the five actions that the robot can take after it senses its state
and and whether it got a reward or not of course there's exploration and exploitation happening at the same time
so what we did in this project was to show how contextual multi-armed Bandits
could be used to learn expected rewards throughout exploration in an online way
so you have the fingertip moving we have up here in the upper left how the
impedance electrode values change whether they're getting squished towards the core or bulging away from the core
we have down here a classification of the state and then some reward or zero
that goes along with that and once we learn a policy for this we
demonstrated the learn policy on other types of bags that were not used during training and these happen to be more
flexible you may have recognized the McMaster Car bags in the in the previous video These are more
soft flexible ones that you'd find in the kitchen and we also tried it with different loading conditions which we had not
trained upon
and there's a lot of we had to speed it up because of the motion planning delay that wasn't something that the student
was very motivated to to fix and and find with me that was not the point of
the study so I was happy with this um the other hard to code task that we
recently completed with a little more sophisticated reinforcement learning was turning a page in a notebook which
sounds very simple for us but it's surprising how related your action is to
the tactile stimuli that you get and we can actually pick up on very subtle changes in what's going on at the
fingertip even with just grabbing a piece of paper which I'll show you in a couple slides so we had a Canova arm
biotech sensors we had binders here with Pages we threw on motion capture markers
because our reward function took into account how the multimodal tackle sensor
data diverge from what we call a functional set of data as well as a
binder movement so if the binder moved too much then we would call that an aggressive movement
so I'll show you here these different three different classes of page flipping
behaviors that we use to demonstrate reinforcement learning in a model-free
way using tactile sensor data and we had to make up some kind of Ideal functional ideal so we we decided that it would be
this one where it's a semicircular trajectory just imagine the fingertips kind of following a half circle
and then we had other undesired page flipping behaviors one is with page
warping and snapping so you can imagine if if there's a radius for that semicircular trajectory and you decrease
that radius now you're going to force the page to warp and then when it gets
turned over here you'll see it snap and we can actually pick up the transient of the snap with our biotech and then if
you imagine that now that radius is increased now you're pulling too much
and too hard and you'll get the binder movement that we penalized for in our reward function
of all these three cases I think the one that's most interesting to watch is the page warping and snapping
there's the warping there's the snap
and so at the end of the day the pages always get turned but they're turned in different ways and in this example we
were trying to show that the tactile sensory data changes in a different way so don't bother yourselves with the
interest intricacies of the data but I just wanted to show you that we have different responses for the top finger
and the bottom finger they experience different things within each of the fingers depending on where you are on
the finger the electrodes experience different things and then depending on the page flipping behavior that you get
different responses so the aggressive trajectories are shown in red you can
see these little spikes for the blue with the snapping of the pages and we were trying to get the robot to learn
you know even if starting with a sub-optimal type of trajectory can it
learn to adjust its its motion roll out according to tactile sensor data only to
get back to something that is more ideal in our case and so we were able to do that and not
only were we able to do that for a nominal trajectory but then we showed that we could adapt and learned nominal
trajectory to different contexts so if you learned on small pages and and then
um we're told to adapt to a different context like large Pages or vice versa
you would necessarily have to change the radius of your trajectory and the robot was able to do that using tactile sensor
data so the left column is the the first policy update and by the time we were
happy with the performance that's the right column
so even starting with a sub-optimal movement after a certain number of policy updates using the tactile sensor
data we could get to something that we considered to be ideal

so a little bit more about what we're doing with Dustin he launched the human fusions Institute which is aimed at

and I'm not saying that that you know teleoperation telepresence tell existence is anything new that has you
know tele existence was created I think back in the 80s and in Japan um this but I think there's a renewed

from a functional perspective to embodiment where it's about enhancing
not only the operators social experience but the experience of the people that

X prize competition and we only had I think six to nine months to put
something together so we went a totally different way from the groups that you
may have viewed either in person or via live stream at the finals about a week ago
um the typical approach is to get very large robotic arms have two of them so
you can do bimanual things Mount them to a mobile base and have this gigantic mobile manipulator and maybe have an

Avatar mimics we went a completely opposite way because we we wanted to do something that would really focus on the
operator's experience and so and also safety so this is the stretch robot from
Hello robot it purposely has a very small footprint it's very lightweight it's meant to go in homes and be used by
individuals with impairment it does not have a Serial linkage arm it has more of a Gantry style arm
and we took off the passive suction cup gripper style end effector and put on
this Tech this sensorized prosthetic hand that Dustin already had access to
and then we took the the Intel real sense you know the RGB D camera and we

the operator system had electric Electro tactile haptic display and was wearing a

operation approaches immersion seamless embodiment intuitive controls multimodal
feedback but again we were really focused on what the operator would experience so we spent a lot of time on

and having this training regime where you know when someone is operating a
robot I think it's different than someone embodying a robot where now you need to think about Perry personal space

journalist when she was in Cleveland she was operating the robot in our lab and I
thought I was being friendly and I popped right in front of the camera and I weaved and said hi Cynthia and it startled her because she didn't have the

them but I had not thought of her as in that way and so I think both from the
operator's perspective and the other interactors there are some social
etiquette things that that still need to be worked out if we're really going to head towards embodiment as opposed to

operator which are the ability to have binocular vision and control where
you're looking as if in an egocentric way and then having some tactile sensation on the
hand these are not the greatest tactile sensors but they are cheap and already

Heckle sensing when you have visual visual tactile synchrony it's actually a
very powerful combination so I have one more funny anecdote you
might enjoy which is we were setting up this demo for a VIP visitor and I wanted
to make sure I tested it and when I tested it and they I closed my eyes they said you're engaged I open my eyes I saw

of like the Hermione Granger experience if you know Harry Potter where you see yourself from this third person
